abstract.p: Joys and perils of riding in concept cars, which are designed to be seen and not necessarily driven, noted; photos (M)

block.p: WHAT we have here is a failure to communicate.

I am sitting in the Buick LaCrosse concept car, a design study for an elegant, futuristic sedan, at General Motors' proving grounds here. And like Paul Newman in the ''Cool Hand Luke'' chain gang, it looks as though I won't be getting out soon.
WHAT we have here is a failure to communicate.

I am sitting in the Buick LaCrosse concept car, a design study for an elegant, futuristic sedan, at General Motors' proving grounds here. And like Paul Newman in the ''Cool Hand Luke'' chain gang, it looks as though I won't be getting out soon.

The LaCrosse's features include voice-activated controls. After a brief and very gentle drive with Gary Mack, one of the car's designers, as I conversed with the car in an attempt to make my exit, I had the distinct sense that I was dealing with HAL, the control-freak computer in ''2001: A Space Odyssey.'' This is what happened:
Me: LaCrosse, door open.
LaCrosse: (Silence.)
Me: LaCrosse, door open.
LaCrosse: Dialing 921.
Me: LaCrosse, door open.
LaCrosse: Out of range.
Mack: Try ''Door open.''
Me: Door open.
LaCrosse: Opening hood.
Mack (quickly trying to take over as the hood starts to rise), loudly: Hood close!
It is an extremely windy day and the prospect that the fragile, hand-built hood will fly open panics three of the car's handlers and sends them running our way.
A G.M. representative: No. No. No. It's too windy! It'll become a sail!
Mack: Hood close.
LaCrosse: Temperature set 79 degrees.
Mack: Hood close.
LaCrosse: Stopping trunk.
Mack: Hood close.
LaCrosse: Closing hood.
Just as I was about to shout, ''Open sesame,'' Mr. Mack coaxed the LaCrosse to open my door and allow me to escape.

Such is life when driving concept cars -- which after all, are designed to be seen and not necessarily to be driven, or even usually to be heard. But it is hard to resist when G.M. offers a chance for even a short drive in $20 million worth of futuristic hardware.

One does not drive these vehicles to evaluate their dynamics. Rather, it's an exercise in make-believe, like sitting in your father's car in the driveway when you were 7, sawing at the steering wheel and imagining that you were on the road.
But this is better because there is a little more than make-believe. You can drive them up to about 25 m.p.h. and get a glimpse of what they'd be like as production models.
For instance, not far from the surly LaCrosse is the Hummer H2, a smaller, more deluxe version of the military vehicle.

After 15 days and 6,000 miles in a race-prepared Hummer in the 1996 Granada-Dakar off-road race, I much prefer the H2 with its leather bucket seats and leather, suede and aluminum interior touches. Plus, there is a Hummer-sized canvas sunroof the size of Rhode Island.

Also nearby is the Chevrolet SSR, for Super Sports Roadster, which has the visual impact of the Plymouth Prowler but is much more practical, thanks to a pickup bed with a hard cover. One of six concept vehicles on hand, it is a sure bet for production.

In an inelegant move, I fall down and over the sill into the cockpit. The driver's seat doesn't slide; we don't have working seat belts; and the speedometer and other electronics are shut off to save battery power. But we have plenty of other power. The 6-liter V-8 can send more than 300 horsepower to the rear wheels.

I turn the key and fire up the engine. I'm holding a large, three-spoke steering wheel, a design cue from the past. The automatic transmission is shifted with a button on the steering wheel. Three taps and I'm in ''drive''; a second later, we're moving.
The ride is stiff, even on the ultra-smooth track, and the body shakes.
''They are all hand-built cars,'' said Andre Hudson, a 23-year-old designer. ''This is actually one of the best ones; the other ones are quite a bit more fragile.''
The tires don't help the ride. The tread was hand-cut by Goodyear in a pattern that mimics Chevy's bow-tie emblem.

But the SSR changes direction quickly, and you realize how strong a performer it will be if G.M. keeps the weight down. The truck's potential is impressive. Plus, when we finish the drive, it lets me out.
